awd_titl_txt: EAR-PF: Clumped and Triple Oxygen Isotopes of Terrestrial Carbonates: New Tools to Estimate Aridity and Precipitation in California During Past Greenhouse Climates
awd_abstract_narration:
Dr. Julia Kelson has been granted an NSF EAR Postdoctoral fellowship to carry out research and educational activities at the University of Michigan, Ann Arbor. This project investigates the water cycle during climates that are characterized by atmospheres with high concentrations of greenhouse (heat-trapping) gases like carbon dioxide. As long as atmospheric concentrations of greenhouse gases continue to increase, we may observe more evaporation and more seasonally intense precipitation (rain/snow) in future climates. One way to understand such changes in the intensity of the hydrologic cycle is to explore the record of evaporation and precipitation during ancient high carbon dioxide climates, such as those of the early Cenozoic time period (65-30 million years ago). This project will develop a new tool to estimate the intensity of evaporation using ancient soil carbonates and mollusk shells. The chemical composition of these ancient carbonate materials contains information about the temperature of formation and the extent to which the rain/ground water from which they grew was affected by evaporation. Thus, this tool will allow for a simultaneous estimate of earth surface temperature and of aridity. The investigator will convey the importance of understanding ancient environmental change through outreach programs affiliated with the University of Michigan. One program is Earth Camp, which brings underrepresented high school students at no-cost to the university and to the field. Another program is Females Excelling More in Math and Engineering Sciences (FEMMES), which encourages girls to explore their potential in science. 

This project is leveraging two novel stable carbonate isotope measurements to improve our ability to reconstruct aridity and precipitation of ancient climates. This research consists of two components: 1) a modern calibration study, where the isotopic composition of modern soil carbonates and mollusk shells are measured, along with the isotopes of modern meteoric waters, to add to the growing understanding of how the isotopic composition of carbonates reflect their environment, and 2) an application to an ancient greenhouse climate, where these new proxies are applied to a Paleocene section in California that has both paleosol carbonates and mollusks in order to reconstruct past aridity and moisture sources. By targeting environments where marine and terrestrial carbonates are collocated, the investigator can understand the potential seasonal biases that the carbonate materials may impart as well as different aspects of the hydrologic cycle.

This award reflects NSF's statutory mission and has been deemed worthy of support through evaluation using the Foundation's intellectual merit and broader impacts review criteria.

por.por_cntn:
The availability of water is a primary control on the landscape, climate, and ecosystem that develops in a region. Society faces uncertainties in how water availability, as determined by precipitation and evaporation patterns, may change under future changing climate conditions. Geologists seek to contextualize ongoing changes in rainfall and drought by characterizing its variability during extreme climates of the ancient past. However, it has been challenging to estimate water availability on land in geologic time because of a lack of geochemical tools that are widely applicable and quantitative. To address this gap, we developed geochemical techniques that can be applied to reconstruct water balance in the geologic rock record. We focused the chemical composition of carbonate minerals that form at the surface of the earth and record environmental conditions at the time of their crystallization. Specifically, we contributed to the development of two relatively novel geochemical techniques, clumped and triple oxygen isotopes, and their applications to shells and soil carbonates. We sought to understand the systematics of clumped and triple oxygen isotopes by studying their distributions in modern soil carbonates and shells. We also studied clumped and triple oxygen isotope measurements of Paleogene oyster shells from paleo-coastal California to reconstruct moisture sources and ancient elevations during this critical climate period in geologic history. 

The data produced in this study laid the foundation for future workers to reconstruct evaporation patterns in ancient soils by 'calibrating' the isotope measurements in modern soils.  We provided stable isotope data (clumped and triple oxygen isotopes) from soil carbonates in a global survey of climates. We showed triple oxygen isotopes can be used to directly identify evaporation from soil carbonates. We discovered a wedge-like relationship between aridity and the amount of evaporation recorded in soil carbonates. This discovery suggests that biotic processes (rootwater uptake, soil respiration) may play an important role in forming soil carbonates even in arid places, a finding that will inform interpretations of paleoclimate records.

We also provided an example of how to use these new geochemical techniques to investigate hydroclimate in the rock record. We used paired measurements of clumped and triple oxygen isotopes in ancient oyster shells from the Goler Formation, a near sea-level basin in present day southern California. The Goler Formation is comprised of sedimentary rocks deposited by ancient rivers and an estuary. We measured light stable isotope compositions in the oyster shells that could only be explain by water fed by high elevations in the ancient (about 50-million-year-old) Sierra Nevada. This understanding of ancient topography is critical because the presence of mountain ranges controls precipitation amounts and surface temperatures on regional basis. We show that without clumped and triple oxygen isotopes, we would have under-estimated the height of the mountain range at that time.

The scientific results were disseminated through presentations at three conferences, invited talks at universities, and three peer-reviewed publications.  This award contributed to the professional development of the PI, an early-career, female scientist. The fellow received training in research, laboratory management, mentoring, and teaching from three supervisors, each with a distinct expertise. The project also provided training for students, including four undergraduate researchers, and one graduate student who was a coauthor on one of the publications. The PI participated in activities to encourage broader participation in the geosciences including peer-mentoring for female scientists through the Association of Women in Science and mentoring of high school student research.
